The `browser()` function stops or halts your running code and starts something called an environment browser that lets you explore variables and functions. Unlike breakpoints, its a line in your code. As it's part of your code it requires no special applications / or tools to activate.

The below example stops your code before returning TRUE

![](images/debug.png)

This and other debugging information is available here:

<https://support.rstudio.com/hc/en-us/articles/205612627-Debugging-with-RStudio#browser>

A tutorial on using `browser()` is here:

<https://riptutorial.com/r/example/5482/using-browser>

Happy debugging!
